comment_1: BrainNevelle, if you just want to hear Maynard sing without the other 3 members then you aren't a Tool fan. Tool is one of if not the best band out there because of all it's members. Danny Carey may be the best drummer ever, and without his complex and powerful polyrythms Tool and Maynard would have no backbone to their songs. Same goes for the gripping and thundering guitar riffs and baselines by Adam Jones and  Justin Chancellor. You have no right to call anyone a fake fan.. if people are true fans, they listen to the whole band. Not just Maynard, don't get me wrong, I still think he is a god, but you have to get the whole picture. If Maynard wanted himself to be more prominent he would have done so. You probably have no appreciation for songs like Reflection on Lateralus.
comment_2:
Regarding what BrainNeville has pointed out, I also agree that vocals in the song are on the background. But this is not something new for Tool at all. There are many examples where Maynard used his voice like an "instrument with words". My examples would be Reflection, You Lied, No Quarter and parts of other songs to. 

Interviews have also shown that Tool has aimed to use Maynard's voice like an instrument via effects and tricks. My counter argument is that we have to stop idealizing Maynard which makes us unable to concentrate on the music that these 4 talents make. 

This is teamwork and why do we always have to see an idol, a frontman. Maynard is no Kurt Cobain. It's his style. Every single individual in Tool sees that all the other guys have suplendid talents and they like to present the whole picture. I appreciate and agree that Maynard has a extraordinarily divine voice and love listening to him like I'm hearing messeages from above. 

However, due to the reason that Maynard is not a frontman in Tool, and should not be, Maynard's voice should not override those of others. And still, I believe there are adequate (although when it comes to Maynard I never get enough) songs to hear him. 

I hope this new album will be another chance to hear Maynard's voice both infront of all others and as an instrument by himself. I take it either way.
comment_3:
This is more down to earth than usual from Maynard. It hits hard because it is not about hidden meanings. At first, the lack of mystery is almost disappointing for a die-hard. But the song itself is devastating and true tool. The meaning, as I see it: we consume information about the world's tragedies like vultures because, in part, it satisfies a need of ours. Why can't we just admit it? Because this vicariousness is horribly shameful. So we (la, la, la) lie about it. Maynard tells us to accept the truth, though, he really doesn't need or want to 'say it all again'.
This is a song about a human need that Maynard thinks is timeless ('so it is, so it's always been'): living vicariously off other people's tragedy. He does not hope for change, he demands recognition of this ailment. Because maybe we really should be ashamed.

comment_6:
When this album first came out I was listening to Vicarious while driving. I was stuck in traffic behind a taxi that had an advertisement on it for an exhibition called "The Human Body", where various aspects of the body are studied and put on display, like muscle/bone structures, skin fibres, vital organs etc etc. Funnily enough, the photo on the ad was very much like the cover of Lateralus, with the photo of a human being illustrating the layers beneath the skin.
What really caught my attention were the words in bold italic underneath the image: "REAL BODIES ON DISPLAY"

This song really made sense to me after I saw that: I could picture people at the exhibition bypassing all the fake plastic skeletons, respiratory system drawings, etc etc, and heading straight for the "real bodies" where they would stand in droves and "stare like zombies" at this dead body on the table. 

I could also imagine that people "wouldn't give pause" to even consider going to the exhibition until they learn that real dead bodies are on display. And the fact that the advertisers found it necessary to even mention it on the ad as if that makes the whole experience more "appealing".

But the funny thing is: I am no different. I would have been there front row centre, looking at the dead body. Even though it's wrong, you can't help but look. "Why can't we just admit it?"

We are all "Part vampire, Part warrior. Carnivore and voyeur." We are infatuated at the misfortune and suffering of others. "Like blood to a vampire"

What genius. Thank you Tool.

Anyway, I was late to work that day. But who cares!!!

One last parting thought: Think about all those times you watch TV, or watch a movie, or even watch a motor race and hope for a crash, a murder scene, etc. We are all monsters. We just need to admit it.

comment_10: I think that there is a lot of hidden meaning in the song, just on another level.  If you follow tool, you know that MJK gets a lot of his ideas from many of Jung's psycho/metaphysical theories.  Jung talks about a "shadow self"; that part of all of us that harkens back to a more primitive time when we were animals that killed to survive.  The shadow is that part of us that we connect with as we are walking through a woods say, and we come upon a baby bird on the ground (I got this from a brief overview of Jung I found on the internet - can't remember the reference), anyway we find this baby bird, a part of us naturally wants to rescue the chick and nurture it back to life. But there is that part of us that thinks just for a moment "I could crush the life out of this thing", and thrills at the prospect.  Jung said the more we deny our shadow, the more evident it encrouches onto our psyche.  So we deny we have this dark part of our souls, well then we start dreaming of marching through the woods stomping on baby birds.  So I think that is a lot of what the song is saying, that we can't deny our shadow self, we need to just admit we are dark souls in order to identify it and deal with it.

comment_14:
I think psychologytoday.com best explains this song - "
Why? The answer may lie in the work of evolutionary psychologists and neuroscientists.  Humans seek out news of dramatic, negative events. These experts say that our brains evolved in a hunter-gatherer environment where anything novel or dramatic had to be attended to immediately for survival. So while we no longer defend ourselves against saber-toothed tigers, our brains have not caught up.

Many studies have shown that we care more about the threat of bad things than we do about the prospect of good things. Our negative brain tripwires are far more sensitive than our positive triggers. We tend to get more fearful than happy. And each time we experience fear we turn on our stress hormones."

comment_16:
I don't think this song is so much a view on society as it is an inward look at himself.  I think he's describing himself.

There's a sub-culture on the internet - and out in the real world for that matter - who watch videos and look for pictures of people being killed in homicides, accidents, war footage etc.  As many people know, there are websites dedicated to wholly to this kind of content.  I remember as a kid the old rotten.com webpage.  Think that but much, much worse.

I believe Maynard is describing himself as one of these people.  A person that needs to watch gore, killing, maiming etc. under some kind of almost compulsion hence the lyric:

"I NEED to watch things die"
is used instead of
"I WANT to watch things die".
There is a massive difference between 'need' and 'want' and I'm sure the use of 'need' is intentional.

The theory is also supported by the lyric that follows where he states he needs to watch things die "from a good safe distance" as although you are seeing intense images of destruction and death, it is still from the safety of your office or living room.

People that view this content do not do so necessarily because they like death, or because they want the person in the video to die.  They do it because it's one of the most extreme things you can watch.  It's about violence getting one step more violent hence the lyric:

"That's my kind of story
It's no fun until someone dies"

I think that speaks to his need for the images he's seeing to go all the way, and show that last precipice of violence.  He needs to see that death, or it wasn't satisfying content.

NOW, you might be thinking, what kind of sick person would watch that crap?  You'd have to be sick right?  Well, that's what Maynard is addressing in the second verse.  With the lyrics:

"Don't look at me like
I am a monster
Frown out your one face
But with the other
Stare like a junkie
Into the TV
Stare like a zombie
While the mother
Holds her child
Watches him die
Hands to the sky crying
"Why, oh why?""

Maynard is explaining, quite obviously, don't look at me like I'm some kind of sicko for watching this.  You will sit there and judge me, yet you watch NBC or Fox News every night and watch the same thing.  Death, killing, destruction.  Every night.  Hence the lyric:

You all need it too, don't lie
Why can't we just admit it?
Why can't we just admit it?
We won't give pause until the blood is flowing

He's saying why can't we all just admit, all we really want to see is violence.

furthermore the song sounds too much like a rehashing of old tool material... try listening to the intro to vicarious and the section in "Pushit" where maynard starts singing "you know that i will choke until i swallow". too similar in rhythm, melody line and syncopation to be a comfort. 

what also bothered me was the fact that there wasn't ONE memorable moment on the song. it's very verse chorus verse chorus driven... very very unlike tool. 

overall after listening to the 13th step album... esp Vanishing, blue, weak & powerless, and previous albums of tool ... this song turns out to be just an extend arm of the aforementioned. sort of like an unhealthy tumour. an unnecessary corrupted replica of what is healthy.

turning the pages. lyrically speaking, this has to be the weakest, the most two dimensional tool piece. like it or not. maynard has constructed the lyrics upon a very unstable ground. the ground being the word "vicarious". unlike previous tool songs, this piece is just too shallow. don't think i'm just one of those lovers of the "abstruse"... this piece as i've said is too two dimensional. there lacks usage of surrealistic techniques found through most of other tool pieces...

if the remainder of the album flows this way, then i'll be quite dissappointed... i guess artists have their period of "wane"... even tool.

tool only progresses more as they play. this song wasn't, at least personally, as much a disappointment as others see it. as a musician (drummer/pianist), i've used tool for many inspirational paths through music. one thing tool's never been able to do is not impress me. no true fan can truly say that this song didn't impress them, as it shows how much each member has progressed.  the lyrics, i must say, were a pain to make out at parts, but it generally flows well.

as for the meaning of this song, from my perspective:
TV (or other medium) all create barriers within us which guard us from "proper" ways of being. this lack of censorship, even through all the censorship, gives us the opportunity to take in what's wrong, and think it's right. it also shows how primitive the human race is, as we're all so interested at the harming (or death) of another, proving how "civilized" we actually are. 

as for BrianNeville, and the other arguing this point:
a band is not like britney spears, where we only stare at one person for hours on end. no, tool (and the majority of bands) are bands without a front man. each instrumental is as impressive as the other, each member contributes equally, if not more. true tool fans listen to the music because it is inspirational, and that you can receive influence for nearly any instrument, as we can see with the string tributes. please, don't say something biased unless it's an opinion on the meaning of the song.

comment_99:
I have bee a tool fan since the first time I heard them in '94.  Tool as a band: voice, guitar, drums... has always stood out amongst the others.  This CD is good.   It is observant of human nature.  It is different than the ones that cam before it, and that is why TOOL has been a viable, meaningful and educational, artistic force.  
If for a second any the members considered taking  some of these warped opinions to heart, they would not be TOOL, they would not be good, they would be Limp Bizkit or some other fluff.
MJK is very political in this song.  Many artists are becoming so.  And to those of you who complain about that:
MAYBE? MAYBE? MJK has allowed himself to be affected by what is going on in the world, by the choices and actions his government is making.  Maybe some of us should allow ourselves to be more affected, rather than numb.  Rather than using music to escape or aid in our oblivion, we need more music to WAKE US UP!!!.  Clearly MJK has political opinions ------  "GO back to sleep" (APC)
This song continues the same point of view.  TREXOR you were off on the whole def. of vicarious, and you are kind of coming across as a tool; but, you were on the right track with the word "numb".
Most of America are numb to what we see and hear on the news.  we can hear about murder, rape war or injustice, and turn the TV off and forget about it. 
This is a dangerous war, it can go on for a very long time, because it does not effect the majority of the population on a large scale.  We can go on with our normal lives, the war is on the other side of the world. the murder was on the TV.
Any stirrings of in-justice or calls to action are numbed by the "three ring circus side show" we live in.  We can stay numb because whatever need we may feel to react is fulfilled vicariously through news, TV, propaganda, etc.
THE FACT THAT THERE IS SO MUCH WRONG GOING ON, WITH SO MANY IN DENIAL SHOULD BOTHER YOU MORE THAN mjk SPEAKING UP AND SINGING ABOUT IT.

comment_125:
I'm not so sure that the last couple of lines are correctly listed.  I've listened to the song a fair number of times and this is what it sounds like to me...

"Credulous at best, 
 your desire to believe in
 Angels in the hearts of men
 Pull your head on...( )
 The universe is hostile
 so impersonal
 devour to survive
 so it is, so it's always been"

I'm not quite sure what he is saying where I put the
( ).  It sounds like "Pull your head on out your head
the brazen never listen" but that doesn't really make much sense to me.

As to the meaning of the song, I think it's pretty obvious.  People have a deep seeded desire to watch other people suffering.  It's why people slow down when there is a traffic accident, or why the news is always so depressing.  I think the German's call it schadenfreude.

I don't know if I agree with this, at least not the the extent that the song seems to imply.  I think there are instances where people watching the suffering of others, especially if they don't particularly like the other person.  In general though, I think there is a limit that people enjoy the suffering of others.  When I hear about people being tortured, kids being raped, and things of this nature, I can assure you I get no satisfaction from it.  I think most decent human beings will feel the same way.  That's my take on it anyways.

let's take a brief look at the day of a hardcore alcoholic as compared to a hardcore junkie... under optimal conditions, of course...

the alcoholic wakes up sick... hung over. he must begin drinking as soon as he is awake, not just to fight off the hangover, but to stave off the shakes which are on their way. the drinker drinks until he feels alright, but since alcohol starts seriously losing it's effect about 2 hours after the last drink the alcoholic must continue drinking all day. alcohol being a drug that is difficult to control your high (blood alcohol levels) with, the equilibrium between being too sick to function and too drunk to function becomes blurred... the drunk drinks until he's fucked beyond his ability to maintain and then passes out, only to do it again the next day...

the hardcore junkie wakes up in the morning still groggy headed from his last fix the night before. eventually, he will take his fix, and depending on the size of his habit he will either go back to sleep or go on about his day if he has anything to do. it's not difficult, with heroin, to maintain a level balance of the high. even at his highest, the junkie can walk a straight line, speak coherently, not piss himself in public, not pass out in bad places, not start fights...

anyway, my original point was that thinking about heroin users as lepers or something is foolish. it's just another drug, less harmful to the body than alcohol is... they still use it in hospitals as a matter of fact...

comment_268:
I don't know if this has been posted before but all I hear about in this comment page is how this song only reflects American culture. I think it can go on another level. Let me explain.

Every Tool CD has some underlying theme or tribute that people are forgetting to mention. Each theme on each album is expressed with an Intro, body, and a conclusion. For example: Anema - Intro: Stinkfist talks about how people should start opening their minds to new things. The body is Songs like Hooker with a Penis and Die Eier Von Satan that forces people to think for themselves to understand the situation. The conclusion is Third Eye where Tool finally says, "See, now take this new way of thinking and apply it to your life."

In Lateralus, the theme is to be grateful that you are alive. The intro is The Grudge, saying that it is a waste of time to hold grudges with other people and it will only drain you of your life if you hold one. The body is mainly reflected in Parabol where the hole theme is to be gratefull you are alive, followed by the conclusion that is Disoposition and Reflection that is music that should make a person feel good and alive. Realizing that you should be happy you can smell the flowers; so to speak.

In 10,000 days, the entire theme of the album is Maynard's Mother. Every single song on the album can be a reflection to his Mother. Vicarious, for example, can be interpreted as how Maynard was forced to watch his Mother die slowly. Saying that watching death on the TV is A LOT different than seeing it happen in real life. Also that we shouldn't consider ourself experienced with death if we see it on the idiot-box. Obviously the body of the album is centered on Wings for Marie and 10,000 days. Saying that she should get a free pass into heaven because of the hell she had to endure on earth all while still staying faithful to the almighty. It ends with Right in Two and Viginti Tres. Very solid conclusions to the album. Reflecting that death is never a good thing, no matter what. Viginti Tres is just Maynards way of saying, "Mom, you're home." 

Now to say that this album is inferior to the previous albums of Tool, I believe, is grossly wrong. In fact, I think it is the most personal album Tool has ever made. To express feeling in lyrics, and music so perfectly to reflect a memory of a loved one as they did in this album is a giant feat. The entire album is, in one word, beautiful. I could understand why they took 5 years to create it. It shows how Tool's music has matured through the years. I strongly believe this is one of the highest points in their carrier.

Overall, I think this album has lived up to my eyes. To treat it as, "utter crap" is just a very synical view that unfortuantly many people take up. Tool has progessed further than that to keep the, "world is crap, all I'm going to do is complain about it, " attitude. It was started in Lateralus, it is now evolving into what is 10,000 days.

Dany Carey is the best!

comment_270:
Wow, thoughtful synopsis Offatwork.   I agree with your assessment.  I would add one thing though -- Tool's albums tend to have multiple themes.  In addition to being focused on Maynard's mother, I think another important theme covered is how humanity is destroying the earth as we speak.   Vicarious states "the universe is hostile, so impersonal, devour to survive..." how all creatures - including humans - kill each other as part of the circle of life.  Unfortunately with human population and consumption out of control (and free market economics ignoring environmental costs) humans are destroying ecosystems, and because we go buy our stuff from a clean aisle at walmart we don't realize the impacts we are having...."Vicariously we live as the whole world dies".   Similarly, "Right in Two" speaks to the tendency of mankind to be violent and self-destructive even though we have the intelligence to see the big picture and think outside ourselves:  "repugnant is a creature who would squander the ability to lift an eye to heaven conscious of his fleeting time here." 

As far as your album review, I completely agree.   Most people who have given this CD poor reviews have forgotten the first rule in enjoying Tool's music -- listen to it many times; it will get better and better.

Witness the failure of art within this world.

Please, read that statement carefully.  Art is meant to inspire creativity, it is the tidal wave of energy that is meant to paint our worlds around us, coloring everything so brightly.

Unfortunately, art today is used to stymie that.  We as creative thinkers are all letting the TV screen tell us what to do.  We let the movies take us away from our creativity.  It is creativity explained.  

But its not art's fault.  It is our own in the state of this world.  We are not quite monsters but so many of us are starved.  We are starved for love, feeling, success, and quality of life.  So many of us are alone, and with the internet, there's one more excuse not to be courageous and connect with each other.

We are letting the mediums control us, and we remain starved.  You are not a vampire by choice, but by survival.  When we lose ourselves we become desperate for the energies we don't receive.  We are acting and devouring out of survival, and unfortunately the world, government, and business have mandated this and incorporated it into technology.

It happened as soon as art was contained and transmuted into making a fast buck.

comment_338: well, this is the kind of song that makes me proud that i don't watch televison.  But that doesn't change my human nature.  My human nature, just like yours is that my goal is self preservation.  If you had to choose between dying and watching someone else die, what would you choose?  That is the case here-the television has redefined the way we experience the world around us.  We can now observe things from the comfort of our own homes.  Although there is alot of shit on TV, this song seems to refer specifically to the news.  The news is inundated with stories of death, murder, tragedy, war.  Which is what we should expect right?  After all, what's more exciting: the story of a successful field trip made by an elementary school, or a story of that group of kids dying after their school bus drove into the river?  That is the point of this song- we love tragedy, we love the sensation of still being alive and safe while we are entertained by the information given to us by our televisions.  So, two points to this song- TV is shit, and humans-no matter how much we deny it- are ultimately self centered, self preserving, creatures that feel little remorse in gaining something from the loss of their fellow man

comment_356:
I think a lot of people are overlooking what Maynard may be saying simply because the song is easy to get.

This song, to me, seems almost like a trick. It almost begs you to admit how you are vicarious, and how you can not survive happily until your mind has fed off the sustenance of others' suffering. But then, when you do, you feel no better; there is no peaceful resolve. You realize your own sickness, which you (humanity as a whole) have been trying to deny with all your existence. All that work and effort thrown away, because now you have been tricked into seeing this truth about yourself.

But, this basically goes in flow with The Pot. It gets the point across that you are not much different than the author, and then The Pot rolls along a few songs later and asks, "so why the hell are you waving your finger at me? Ganja, please!" 

Of course, the songs between these two help build a certain guilt that may be present within the listener. We go from a depiction of indulgent, almost sickening, humanity to a person who was so tremendously holy. The comparison makes the listener go from "admit you're fucked up" to "look at this amazing person who no one can ever be" and then rolls into The Pot, basically say "So why the hell do you think you're better than me?"

Sounds reminiscent of certain Christian converting tactics. Perhaps another insult by Maynard to a faith he seems to detest strongly?


I don't know for sure though, maybe I'm giving Tool too much credit. The songs, as an individual and whole, however, flow beautifully, and are just as entertaining to listen to either way.

Ok, so first off, im not about to read 17 pages of a bunch of whiney little girls argueing about whether maynard or tool as a band is better.

There are always going to be tool fans, and there are always going to be maynard fans.  Personally, i like them both.  But i think that the other three memebers of tool don't receive nearly enough recognition.

This song to me is about how it is human nature to feed off the tragedy of others.  It's always been that way -- in roman times, gladitorial arenas -- it is that way now, and like maynard says.. it will probably always be that way.

"Pull your head on out your hippy haze and give a listen.
Shouldn't have to say it all again.
The universe is hostile. so Impersonal. devour to survive."

ok, so all my life i have always been a huge advocate of natural selection.  but once i started doing alot of drugs i realised that natural selection was just the system of the past, and that humans need to be able to move above it.  Hence the "hippy haze".  But what tool is saying here is that we can't move above it, because it is just survival.  If we move above it then we cease to survive.  Now this point of view is understandable, but i respectfully disagree.  One of my favorite sayings is applicable here:

"In a world filled with darkness, it is better to light a single candle than to curse the darkness"

comment_401:
For those interested in the concept which this song presents, I recommend reading "The Birth of Tragedy" by Friedrich Nietzsche as well as Arthur Schopenhauer's "Essays and Aphorisms"...

Arthur Schopenhauer pessimisticly illustrate the idea that suffering is the only thing guaranteed in the world, so in turn it would be foolish to assume that anything besides suffering holds any true meaning. We need suffering in order to give value to the pleasure in our lives.

In the Birth of Tragedy, Friedrich Nietzsche (inspired by Schopenhauer) goes on to say that tragedy is actually an affirmation of life - we catalyze the tragedy in art to express and reflect the injustice and chaos which we have experienced in life, in turn relieving the burden of the suffering.

comment_428:
I think psychologytoday.com best explains this song - "
Why? The answer may lie in the work of evolutionary psychologists and neuroscientists.  Humans seek out news of dramatic, negative events. These experts say that our brains evolved in a hunter-gatherer environment where anything novel or dramatic had to be attended to immediately for survival. So while we no longer defend ourselves against saber-toothed tigers, our brains have not caught up.

Many studies have shown that we care more about the threat of bad things than we do about the prospect of good things. Our negative brain tripwires are far more sensitive than our positive triggers. We tend to get more fearful than happy. And each time we experience fear we turn on our stress hormones."

comment_440:
They are talking about today's world, with TV. But when I listen to this song I always consider that this is not new behavior for humans. Death has always been entertainment, as long as it happens to someone else. Lynchings were a popular attraction throughout Europe and America until 100 years ago. The Romans pitted slaves against each other in fights to the death. It's a big morbid circus. Modern media just gives us easy access.

Maybe it all goes back to the Jungian shadow stuff that og_tool has enlightened us with. That was an awesome comment.

Another interpretation of my own, which is not supported much by the lyrics I admit, is that God is the one vicariously experiencing death through our mortality. God can't die, so he made life that way. It is cruel. We are made in God's image, sharing his nature while being human, so we are cruel. But, I don't know if this song is actually saying anything about God.
